body: Please see the section [Reporting a monitor or video mode bug](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#reporting-a-monitor-or-video-mode-bug).
Please also submit any text as text, not as images. It will help others to find this issue.

Sorry for the mistake. This is my first time using an issues forum of any kind.

Windows 10 64-bit
GLFW 3.2.1

I ran the monitor.c file, and I get this output:

Name: Acer E202HL (Digital) (primary)
Current mode: 1600 x 900 x 24 (8 8 8) 60Hz
Virtual Position: 1920 0

And the rest of the info is about different modes and the physical size.

The problem with this output is that the name of the monitor is my primary monitor, but the current mode of the monitor is actually my secondary monitor, which is an Emacs monitor with analog input (forgot the model name).
Are both monitors part of the Windows desktop?

If you mean that Windows recognizes both monitors, then yes.

If you need more information about the monitors themselves:

Primary Monitor:
Acer E202
Digital connection
19280x1080 60Hz

Secondary Monitor:
Emacs
Logically registered as to the left of the primary monitor in Windows
Analog connection
1600 x 900 60 Hz

I don't know how useful this information is, but the more the merrier.

Thank you, that is useful.

Please post the output of [this tool](https://github.com/elmindreda/monitool).

Unfortunately, I'm in college right now and away from my setup. I'll be back home during the weekend and I'll run the test.

Sorry for the inconvenience.

Thank you! That seems to explain every part of the behavior you describe.

GLFW isn't listing your actual primary monitor because it doesn't have a display device (e.g.  `"\\.\DISPLAY1\Monitor0"`), but it doesn't switch to using adapter devices (e.g. `"\\.\DISPLAY1"`) for GLFW monitors because the other adapter device _does_ have one (adapter device-only GLFW monitors has so far been a VMware specific workaround). Since the convention in GLFW is that the first monitor in the array is the primary one, the display device of the second adapter device implicitly becomes primary.

At this point I would like to know more about your "Emacs" monitor? What is it? Hardware or emulated? How is it connected? Is the Windows display dialog and/or device manager aware of it? If so, what is is called there?
